## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
library(bigrquery)

project_id <- "hst-953-2018"
options(httr_oauth_cache=FALSE)

run_query <- function(query){
  data <- query_exec(query, project=project_id, use_legacy_sql=FALSE)
  return(data)
}

get_sql <- function(f){
  con = file(f, "r")
  sql.string <- ""
  while (TRUE) {
    line <- readLines(con, n=1)
    if (length(line) == 0) {
      break
    }
    
    line <- gsub("\\t", " ", line)
    if (grepl("--", line) == TRUE) {
      line <- paste(sub("--", "/*", line), "*/")
    }
    sql.string <- paste(sql.string, line)
  }
  close(con)
  return(sql.string)
}

# test and get auth code
run_query(paste0("SELECT count(1) FROM `physionet-data.mimiciii_clinical`.`patients`"))


```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r}
q <- get_sql("sql/bq-test.sql")
res <- run_query(q)

```
```{r}

q <- get_sql("sql/bq-mimic-crystalloid-bolus.sql")
fluid <- run_query(q)
(fluid)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
